results.title: Aftermath: the defence against disaster
results.brief_description: Civil defense workers carry no guns. Their job is to help where tragedy has become personal reality. This film shows the activities, training and operations of civil defence organisations in Australia. The film is designed to assist in training civil defence recruits in all States and to widen appreciation of the need for civil defence preparedness among the general public in times of both peace and war. Adapted from the film “Aftermath” by Film Australia for the Natural Disasters Organization. No other credits available.

results.title: Aftermath
results.brief_description: Dramatisation of a man who has been disabled and put into a wheel chair after an on-the-job accident. It explores his trials and tribulations of adjusting to a new life and facing his family etc. This film is designed to encourage the audience to think seriously about safety. A Teacher’s Guide is supplied. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: Afterlife
results.creator_credit: Rozlyn Clayton-Vincent, Justin Davies, Dean Francis and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
A female flight attendant on a trans-pacific flight asks the question, “What would you do with the last five minutes of your life?” And sees it answered in the worst-case scenario.
Cast includes Lisa Hensley.

results.title: Afterlife
results.creator_credit: Ishu Patel, Derek Lamb and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: What is dying? How does it feel? Afterlife is an impressionistic and visionary response to these eternal questions. Based on recent studies, case histories, and some of the ancient myths, the afterlife state is portrayed as an awesome but methodical working-out of all the individual’s past experiences. Music performed by Herbie Mann. Nine awards including Montreal, Chicago, Hong Kong, Annecy and Columbus.

results.title: After work
results.brief_description: This film shows that human beings are not machines to be shut down at night; change and recreation are needed to keep well and happy in war or in peace. Of interest to industries, this film demonstrates how factory management, civic groups and workers themselves establish recreational centers, where dancing, swimming, singing, handicrafts and many other sports and hobbies are enjoyed. Canadians use their time after work to become healthy, informed citizens

results.title: After trousers [Widescreen] (A)
results.creator_credit: Richard Curson Smith, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, BBC and Oxford Film and Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Australia: beyond the fatal shore [Widescreen]”.
Art critic Robert Hughes reflects on his relationship to Australia, thirty-five years after leaving the country. Contemplative after his near fatal car accident, Hughes reflects fondly on his childhood in Australia with an appreciation that only came from questioning his mortality. Episode four examines the 200 year history of cross cultural appropriation since Aborigines first made contact with white settlers, a period referred to as “after trousers”. Particular attention is paid to the plight of Aboriginals in Tasmania, from King Billy and Truganini to the claim by current residents of their Aboriginal ancestry. Hughes travels to the home of the Bush mob, the last known group to have made contact with whites in 1984 before being reunited with the rest of their Pintubi community. He also visits Hermansburg Mission and speaks of the influence of Christianity, instilled by Lutheran missionaries over the years as well as touching on the forced removal of aboriginal children. He talks to opera singer Deborah Cheetham, one of the stolen generation, about her relationship with her biological mother and her thoughts on the matter.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Curson Smith, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, BBC and Oxford Film and Television

results.title: After the whale
results.creator_credit: L. Richard Ellison and Time-Life Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life Around Us”.
Probably the most misunderstood animal, the whale is shown in this film to be a playful, shy, browsing mammal, defenceless against us and on the verge of extinction.

results.title: After the Warming
results.creator_credit: Mike Slee, Richard Sattin and Film Australia
results.brief_description: It is the year 2050. Mankind and the earth have survived global warming. In an innovative new television project, social journalist James Burke looks back from the future of several scenarios of global warming and their possible effects on continents, countries and mankind. He explores the preventative roads not taken and the potential results.
